title: Examples
text: Suppose want convert Frequency occurrence (FO) Species percentage cover (%SC), considering also occasional species. %SC survey (likely) greater 100, want rescale %SC species per survey obtain sum 100 (.e. proportion %SC). dataset used example shown “Data input format” vignette, total measurements per transect 25. Therefore, obtain $SC FO multiplied 4 (refer 100 measurements.) can check sum %SC survey 100
code: library(iPastoralist) vegetation.sc<-vegetation_abundance(database = vegetation,                                     species.cover.coefficient = 4,                                     method = "SRA_SC.fo.occ") head(vegetation.sc) colSums(vegetation.sc) #>  R1  R2  R3  R4  R5  R6  R7  R8  R9 R10 R11 R12 R13 R14 R15 R16 R17 R18 R19 R20  #> 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100 100  #> R21 R22 R23 R24  #> 100 100 100 100

title: Examples
text: case want compute average Landolt indicator values survey, weighted species abundance. occasional species considered, SRA used. Conversely, like keep account also occasional species, SRA calculated %SC rescaled 100 (detail “vegetation_abundance” function). case consider also occasional species. input database one Frequency occurrences, .e. dataframe used tutorial named “vegetation”. Notes “ecological_indexes” function: database.indexes = database Ecological indicators, without column species names. NA values must indicated 999 occasional.species = Logical. TRUE want take account occasional species. species.cover.coefficient = “occasional.species=TRUE”. Coefficient multiplies FO number total touches refer 100 weight: Logical. TRUE want weight Ecological indicators abundance. output follow:

what: Example 3 - Matching a dendrogram with vegetation data
title: Examples
text: aim example generate cluster analysis vegetation data, associated dendrogram species survey ordered abundance. approach help cut dendrogram. dataset shown ‘Data input format’ vignette, columns related plant species names surveys selected. , need compute Species Relative Abundance Now can generate dendrogram using hclust function R ‘stats’ base package.  extract first ten species ordered decreasingly SRA survey, can run ‘first_ten_species’ function: output can graphically merged dendrogram: Figure 2 view, can easier identify survey groups based vegetation composition abundance. Suppose identify 8 groups, can visually shown following base plotting functions:  Now, group helful compute average composition. First can extract ID group survey ‘clustOrder’ function: ‘cluster’ column one according vegetation surveys pooled together. Therefore, first need add column database abundances used input dendrogram (.e. ‘db.dendro’ dataset) Lastly, ‘clustGroupAggregate’ function, average composition group can computed:
code: vegetation<-data[,c(2,7:30)] sra<-vegetation_abundance(database = vegetation,method = "SRA_fo") head(sra) db.dendro<-t(sra)#for the cluster analysis the database has to be transposed so to have surveys on rows and species on columns  library(amap)#package for computing a distance matrix d <- Dist(db.dendro, method = "correlation")#distance matrix cluster <- hclust(d, method="average") # clustering method  #plotting the dendrogram par(cex=0.5, mar=c(5, 8, 4, 1))#set label size plot(cluster,cex=0.8,hang =-1,      main=paste0("dMatrix: Correlation","---","clustMet: UPGMA")) firstTenSpecies<-first_ten_species(data_SRA_SC = sra ,#database with species abundance. In this example is the 'sra' database                                     join.dendrogram = TRUE,#LOGICAL. TRUE if species abundance need to be joined with a dendrogram                                    cluster.hclust = cluster)# object of containing the output from 'hclust' function of 'stats' package plot(cluster,cex=0.8,hang =-1) rect.hclust(cluster,k=8,border="red") group.id<-clustOrder(cluster.hclust = cluster,# object of containing the output from 'hclust' function of 'stats' package                       cluster.group = T, #Logical. TRUE if you want to specify the number of groups of the dendrogram.                        cluster.number = 8) # Specify the number of groups. dendro.merge<-merge(group.id,db.dendro,by.x = "Survey",by.y = "row.names") row.names(dendro.merge)<-dendro.merge[,1]#renaming dataset rows dendro.merge1<-dendro.merge[,-c(1,3)]#deleting useless columns aggregate<-clustGroupAggregate(dendro.merge1)

title: Introduction to iPastoralist
text: Botanical composition surveyed either phytosociological point-quadrat / pinpoint (point‐intercept) method (plant species recorded fixed interval along linear transect, Daget Poissonet 1971). botanical composition surveyed point-quadrat / pinpoint (point‐intercept) method, iPastoralist works also list plant species included within buffer area around transect line (.e. vegetation plot) done. Indeed, point-intercept method often miss rare species.

title: Introduction to iPastoralist
text: iPastoralist allows : Species relative abundance (SRA) : ratio frequency occurrence sum frequency occurrences values species transect, multiplied 100; Species percentage cover (%SC): conversion frequency occurrence 100 measurements (e.g. species FO= 20 measurements 50 total measurements along transect line, FO multiplied 2). occasional species (.e. species found within vegetation plots along linear transects) %SC value = 0.3% attributed. details provided vegetation_abundance function, process FO data following workflow: Workflow Biodiversity indexes: Species richness, Shannon diversity index, Effective Number Species (ENS), Shannon max, Equitability. (see “biodiversity” function) Forage Pastoral Value (PV) (see “pastoral_value” function) Ecological indexes: Landolt, Ellenberg (either weighted weighted plant species abundance either considering considering occasional species). (see “ecological_indexes” function) Extract survey firt ten species, ordered decreasingly abundance (useful dendrograms). (see “first_ten_species” function)

title: Introduction to iPastoralist
text: ‘PhytoCover’ function, iPastoralist allows transform species cover visually estimated phytosociological survey : Braun-Blanquet cover-abundance scale (Braun-Blanquet,1932) Van Der Maarel cover-abundance scale (Van Der Maarel, 1978) Dominance percentage (Tasser Tappeiner, 2005) Conversion table

title: Introduction to iPastoralist
text: Braun-Blanquet J (1932) Plant sociology. study plant communities. GD Fuller HS Conard (Eds.). Authorized English translations ‘Pflanzensoziologie’. 1st ed. Printed United States America. New York London: McGraw-Hill Book Co. Inc. Daget, P., Poissonet, J., (1971). method plant analysis pastures. Ann. Agron. 22, 5–41. Tasser E, Tappeiner U (2005) New model predict rooting diverse plant community compositions. Ecological Modelling 185:195-211. Van der Maarel, E. (1979). Transformation cover-abundance values phytosociology effects community similarity. Vegetatio, 39(2), 97-114.

Indeed, point-intercept method often miss rare species.

title: Management, conversion, and analyses of vegetation data derived from phytosociological and point-quadrat method surveys
text: iPastoralist allows : Species relative abundance (SRA) : ratio frequency occurrence sum frequency occurrences values species transect, multiplied 100; Species percentage cover (%SC): conversion frequency occurrence 100 measurements (e.g. species FO= 20 measurements 50 total measurements along transect line, FO multiplied 2). occasional species (.e. species found within vegetation plots along linear transects) %SC value = 0.3% attributed. details provided vegetation_abundance function, process FO data following workflow: esempio Biodiversity indexes: Species richness, Shannon diversity index (log2), Effective Number Species,Shannon max, Equitability. (see “biodiversity” function) Forage Pastoral Value (PV) (see “pastoral_value” function) Ecological indexes: Landolt, Ellenberg (either weighted weighted plant species abundance either considering considering occasional species). TRUE want take account occasional species. occasional species considered, SRA correspond "SRA_SC.fo.occ" (see vegetation_abundance) species.cover.coefficient "occasional.species=TRUE". Coeffient multiplies FS number total touches refer 100 weight Logical. TRUE want weight Ecological indicators SRA.

title: Computation of Pastoral Value (PV) — pastoral_value
text: database PV computed per survey

title: Computation of Pastoral Value (PV) — pastoral_value
text: forage productivity quality can expressed Pastoral Value (PV), unique synthetic index derived sward botanical composition summarizing forage yield, quality, palatability livestock (Daget Poissonet, 1969, Pittarello et al. 2018, 2020). PV, ranges 0 100, computed according following formula (Daget Poissonet, 1971): PV = (SRAi ISQi) 0.2 : ISQ: Index specific quality attributed species epends preference, morphology, structure, productivity plant species. ranges 0 (low) 5 (high) (Daget Poissonet, 1971; Cavallero et al., 2007). SRA: Species Relative Abundance species within survey computed either 'SRA_fo' 'SRA_SC.fo.occ' (see vegetation_abundance) attributed species Index specific quality (ISQ)

title: Computation of Pastoral Value (PV) — pastoral_value
text: Cavallero, ., Aceto, P., Gorlier, ., Lombardi, G., Lonati, M., Martinasso, B., Tagliatori, C., (2007). tipi pastorali delle Alpi piemontesi. (Pasture types Piedmontese Alps). Alberto Perdisa Editore. p. 467, Bologna. Daget, P., Poissonet, J., 1969. Analyse phytologique des praries, Centre Nat. ed, Applications agronomiques. Montpellier - France Daget, P., Poissonet, J., 1971. method plant analysis pastures. Ann. Agron. 22, 5–41. Pittarello, M., Lonati, M., Gorlier, ., Perotti, E., Probo, M., Lombardi, G., 2018. Plant diversity pastoral value alpine pastures maximized different nutrient indicator values. Ecol. Indic. 85, 518–524. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecolind.2017.10.064 Pittarello, M., Lonati, M., Ravetto Enri, S., Lombardi, G., 2020. Environmental factors management intensity affect different ways plant diversity pastoral value alpine pastures. Ecol. Indic. 115, 106429. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecolind.2020.106429

what: Transformation of visually estimated cover (%) in a phytosociological survey to cover-abundance values — PhytoCover
title: Transformation of visually estimated cover (%) in a phytosociological survey to cover-abundance values — PhytoCover
text: Species cover visually estimated phytosociological survey transformed : Braun-Blanquet cover-abundance scale (Braun-Blanquet,1932) Van Der Maarel cover-abundance scale (Van Der Maarel, 1978) Dominance percentage (Tasser Tappeiner, 2005) see @details

title: Transformation of visually estimated cover (%) in a phytosociological survey to cover-abundance values — PhytoCover
Transformation of visually estimated cover (%) in a phytosociological survey to cover-abundance values — PhytoCover
text: database database visually estimated cover plant species. Rare species added '+". Rows species columns surveys. first column database reports species names (Important: space among words must exist). Database class must data.frame method "BrBl": transform cover visually estimated Braun-Blanquet cover-abundance scale (see @details ) "Maarel": transform cover visually estimated Van Der Maarel cover-abundance scale (see @details ) "TassTapp": transform cover visually estimated dominance percentage according Tasser Tappeiner (2005) (see @details )

title: Transformation of visually estimated cover (%) in a phytosociological survey to cover-abundance values — PhytoCover
text: Conversion table

title: Transformation of visually estimated cover (%) in a phytosociological survey to cover-abundance values — PhytoCover
text: Braun-Blanquet J (1932) Plant sociology. study plant communi- ties. GD Fuller HS Conard (Eds.). Authorized English translations 'Pflanzensoziologie'. 1st ed. Printed United States America. New York London: McGraw-Hill Book Co. Inc. Van der Maarel, E. (1979). Transformation cover-abundance values phytosociology effects community similarity. Vegetatio, 39(2), 97-114. Tasser E, Tappeiner U (2005) New model predict rooting diverse plant community compositions. Ecological Modelling 185:195-211.

what: Transform Frequency of occurrence (FO) to Species relative abundance (SRA) or Species percentage cover(%SC) — vegetation_abundance
title: Transform Frequency of occurrence (FO) to Species relative abundance (SRA) or Species percentage cover(%SC) — vegetation_abundance
text: database Frequency occurrences species identified along linear transect occasional species (.e. species found within vegetation plots along linear transects), Species relative abundance (SRA) percentage species cover(%SC) computed, either considering considering occasional species. Terminology: Frequency occurrence (FO) : number species occurrences 'N' points vegetation measurements along transect line Species relative abundance (SRA) : ratio frequency occurrence sum frequency occurrences values species transect, multiplied 100 Species percentage cover (%SC): conversion frequency occurrence 100 measurements (e.g. species FO= 20 measurements 50 total measurements along transect line, FO multiplied 2). occasional species (.e. species found within vegetation plots along linear transects) %SC value = 0.3% attributed. see MarcoPittarello/iPastoralist full graphical explanation

title: Transform Frequency of occurrence (FO) to Species relative abundance (SRA) or Species percentage cover(%SC) — vegetation_abundance
Transform Frequency of occurrence (FO) to Species relative abundance (SRA) or Species percentage cover(%SC) — vegetation_abundance
text: database database FO occasional species 999. Rows species columns surveys. first column database reports species names. Database class must data.frame method "SRA_fo": SRA calculated FO without occasional species.see MarcoPittarello/iPastoralist full graphical explanation "SC_fo": %SC calculated multiplying FO coeffient number total measurements along transect line refer 100 (occasional species excluded). see MarcoPittarello/iPastoralist full graphical explanation "SC_fo_occ": like SC_fo addition occasional species, considered 0.3%. total %SC  per surveys > 100 %. see MarcoPittarello/iPastoralist full graphical explanation "SRA_SC.fo.occ": SRA calculated SC_fo_occ, .e. rescale SC_fo_occ total sum per survey sum 100 %. see MarcoPittarello/iPastoralist full graphical explanation species.cover.coefficient Coeffient multiplies FO number total touches refer 100. required method = "SC_fo_occ","SC_fo", "SRA_SC.fo.occ"
